newsitem.title: USA: Glickman seeks more FY98 food safety funds.
newsitem.headline: Glickman seeks more FY98 food safety funds.

text.p: U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman Tuesday urged House appropriators to boost funding for a Clinton administration intitiative aimed at reducing food-borne deaths and illnesses.
"As the appropriations stand today, USDA has been given only about a third of the money it needs to carry (the initiative) out," Glickman said in a speech to agricultural industry lobbyists.

In February, the Clinton adminstration requested $43.2 million in new funding for food safety surveillance, research and education efforts, including $34 million for the Food and Drug Administration and the Center for Disease Control and $9.2 million for USDA.

Last month, the House Appropriations subcommittee on agriculture approved just $17 million for additional food safety efforts. Despite the shortfall, food safety was one of the few areas in the agriculture and FDA budget to receive any year-to-year increase.

The subcommittee also eliminated funding for a high level food safety postion at USDA--a move that subcommittee staff described as a "poke" at the administration for taking a long time to fill the post.

Having made their point, lawmakers are expected restore funding for the food safety slot when the full House Appropriations Committee takes up the fiscal 1998 agriculture department spending bill Wednesday afternoon.

Over the weekend, the Clinton administration finally sent the paperwork on its nominee for the food safety slot--current USDA Deputy Secretary for Research, Education and Econonics Catherine Wotecki--to the Senate Agriculture Committee.
Glickman also expressed concern Tuesday about a $60 million cut in conservation program funding and a $100 million cut in rural rental assistance approved by the subcommittee.
But "by and large," the panel's bill is a reasonable effort given current tough budget constraints, he said.
